comment_by: Liz’s Lil’ Corner of the Institution
comment_text:
I came upon Crash Course by way of SciShow. I have an unending curiosity to the extent I’m pretty sure my first word was “why”! (Granted that got me into more trouble as a kid but thankfully that trouble couldn’t kill the curiosity!)

Speaking for myself, I must say there’s something addicting about learning when the person teaching truly loves their topic!

Most people find it strange that I prefer videos like these but have little to no interest in watching tv. My thought... why watch fiction when reality is so much more interesting, fascinating and even frightening!?

The only thing I can think of as a “tweak” to this series... I’d love for there to be ‘add ons’ as new things are discovered. Other than that, I love the series and appreciate everyone who works to make these available! Thank you!!!

At my local(ish) planetarium, they have this shiny chunk of rock about two/three adult fists big or so, with a sign saying "This is a metallic meteorite that fell in (place) in (year). See how heavy it is!" and it's attached to this sliding rod thing so you can lift it a bit.  Probably lots of planetariums/science museums have something like that, but I still think it's cool that ordinary people can just walk up and touch a chunk of outer space.  :)

To summarize:
Asteroid - Small rocky object which is not round.
Comet - Asteroid with a trail.
Meteor - Asteroid heading towards our planet
Meteorite - Asteroid in the atmosphere
Meteoroid - Asteroid landed on Earth

So, Phil Plait blocks people who speak their mind about a nut job like Jim Carry, then apologizes on slate for offending the LGBTQ ( am I missing any letters?) community for a visual gag on one of your videos. I thought this was a man of "free thinking". He went on to say that people don't have the right to decide what others consider offensive, which he is absolutely right about. The point he seems to be missing is, no free country has a law that provides freedom from being offended. Offending someone isn't a crime.  If this sort of behavior(hypersensitivity to virtually anything) is not only permitted but encouraged, through apologies and self censorship, then soon any rational conversation won't be permissible out of fear of offending someone. Thankfully, our forefathers (USA) didn't feel this way or we'd still be under English rule. There's no way you can have CHANGE in a country without offending people. People in SC are offended that people want their flag removed, people in TX are offended that certain groups don't want creationism taught in science class. If you are offended by something, good, that's how life is supposed to work. Just another example of the pussafication of our country. Everyone gets a trophy, no child left behind, no one's feelings are aloud to be hurt. Our country was built and maintained on the mental fortitude of it's people, not by the people who whined and cried every time their feelings got hurt.

A shooting star is not a star,
it's not a star at all.
A shooting star's a meteor,
that's heading for a fall.

A shooting star is not a star,
why does it shine so bright?
The friction as it falls though air
produces heat and light.

A shooting star or meteor,
which ever name you like.
The minute it comes down to Earth
it's called a meteorite.

-- Hy Zaret And Lou Singer

10 years ago I was a nightwatchman at a lumber mill, so it tended to be pretty dark during my shift on the weekends...

While on a patrol behind the mill I saw an extremely bright green flash in the sky. At first I thought someone was lighting off fireworks in the distance, but it was actually a meteor.

That also left an afterimage with how bright it was, but it probably helps that it was quite dark to begin with heh. That's the one thing I miss from that job, it was a GREAT chance to stargaze while getting paid in the process lol.

http://meteorites.wustl.edu/id/density.htm
The most common meteorite has a a density of 3.40g/cm^3 which is 3.40*10^(-6)kg/mm. If the meteoroid was a sphere 1mm in diameter which is close to size of sand, then the total mass is 1.78*10^(-6)kg. At 70km/s or 7.0*10^4m/s, we'd have kinetic energy of 4.4*10^3J. I guess that would be pretty bright.

The dinosaurs were already walking on thin ice when the K-T impact happened. Dinosaurs evolved for a low oxygen world that was perpetuated by Pangea, which had very little coastline and continental shelf and the interior had a lot of desert, so less overall photosynthesis happening. Dinosaurs, along with today's birds, have a respiratory advantage with their lung design, hence why they were able to displace the mammal like reptiles at the end of the Triassic. As the continents split, oxygen got higher and dinosaurs got bigger in the late Jurassic and evolved a lot of giant sauropods. The herbivore pressure on the plants pushed the evolution of flowering plants, which could grow faster and were more effective. Oxygen levels then reached today's levels and the world actually favored mammals. But Triceratops, T-Rex, Parasaurolophus, Ankylosaurus evolved at at that point and they were adapted to eating flowering plants. But then the deccan traps erupted and a new form of plankton that thrived in high oxygen removed a lot of CO2 from the atmosphere in the form of chalk (that the cretaceous was known for) and sea levels dropped. Some scientists think only 10 dinosaur species were left when the impact happened. So it seems that the impact wasn't actually needed to get mammal dominance. Also, I think the ammonites were also adapted to low oxygen like the dinosaurs were.
